Award.AwardTitle: Late Medieval Climate in the Caribbean: Pacific vs. Atlantic control on interannual variability and mean state
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Medieval Climate Anomaly (MCA), an unusually warm period ~1000 years ago that was followed immediately by the Little Ice Age (LIA), represents a possible example of climate response to changes in radiative forcing. Previous work indicates that a change in the tropical Indo-Pacific sea surface temperature gradient may have contributed to the MCA; however, this change does not fully explain climate perturbations during that time, and the potential role of the Atlantic Ocean has yet to be considered.

To fill this critical knowledge gap, a researcher at Chesapeake Biological Laboratory will generate a high-resolution paleoclimate record for the MCA and LIA transition using isotopes (Sr/Ca, δ18O) preserved in coral skeletons from the Caribbean Sea. The Caribbean is particularly well-suited for this study because Caribbean surface temperatures are strongly correlated with global surface temperatures; furthermore, while modeling has suggested a strong Pacific influence on Caribbean climate, this influence has not previously been tested with paleoclimate data. The paleoclimate record produced by this project will overlap temporally with pre-existing records from the tropical Pacific, enabling analysis of the relationship between the Pacific and Atlantic ocean basins with respect to short-term (centennial to inter-annual) climate variability.

Understanding anomalous, short-term events like the MCA has important implications for assessing the limitations of long-term climate predictions. This project will advance knowledge of climate processes and variability in the heavily populated region of the Atlantic tropics. In addition, the project will support student training at the graduate and undergraduate levels, with undergraduate students provided by the Maryland SeaGrant REU program. A female, underrepresented minority student familiar with the study area (Anegada, British Virgin Islands) will participate as a student collaborator, and students at the University of Puerto Rico (a minority-serving institution) have been encouraged to join the field expedition. The field program will provide international experience for all students involved. Ongoing outreach programs at Chesapeake Biological Laboratory will incorporate this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studies of Earth’s climate over the last 1000 years can provide a dataset to test and demonstrate the reliability of climate models used for projections of future climate change. The ultimate goal of this study was to reconstruct the climate in the northern tropical Atlantic over a time and region for which we have little data, thus improving our understanding of the development of the climate system over the last millennium.  We found substantial differences in the seasonal cycle and interannual variability during the late Medieval period compared to today and we are continuing to work to fully understand the observed changes.  Along the way we also contributed to furthering knowledge in this field by working towards: 1) developing the rarely-used coral species Diploria strigosa for future use in reconstructing past climates, 2) improving the statistical treatment of coral-geochemistry data for climate reconstructions. Additionally our study had the added benefit of helping to assess seismic risk in the area by determining the age of the large ocean wave event (likely a tsunami) that washed ashore the coral boulders use for our paleoclimate study.

            The project had impact beyond the scientific implications as well. It enabled the training and mentoring of four undergraduate students and three graduate students, including forming the primary research focus for one Masters student. This MS student, who is originally from China, is now in the final stages of a Ph.D. and I expect will become a productive junior colleague, potentially strengthening future US-China scientific collaborations.  Two of the graduate students who participated in the project were Latino, a demographic that is underrepresented in the Earth Sciences, thus this project played a part in broadening participation in the field.  The research from this study was featured prominently in our institutional outreach activities that strive to increase science literacy in our community. Activities included docent seminars, weekly tours and an exhibit in our visitor’s center.  Further, information from this study will be used by the British Virgin Islands Department of Disaster Management (DDM) for informing the risk of large ocean wave events in the area and the risks of climate variability outside the range of historical climate data.
